awd_titl_txt: Chemical Mechanisms of Inorganic Phototropic Growth
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1: Non-Technical Summary 
Controlled patterning of materials is important for semiconductor integrated circuit fabrication, 3-D electronics, advanced functional biomaterials, optical materials, and catalyst supports.  In this project, jointly supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry and Electronic and Photonic Materials Programs in the Division of Materials Research, Professor Nathan S. Lewis of the California Institute of Technology seeks to develop and exploit a fundamental understanding of inorganic phototropic growth.  In conventional lithography, materials grow where light is present, whereas in phototropic growth, the materials grow toward the light source.  By manipulating the wavelength, intensity, and polarization of the light beams provided by sources as simple as ordinary light bulbs or LEDs, inorganic phototropic growth can spontaneously produce complex, self-organized nanoscale patterns that can be controlled in three dimensions in real time.  Such scientific research is foundational to national competitiveness in materials research, information, optical-communications, nanotechnology, and chemical-sensing.  

To meet the objective of this project, the Lewis Group is exploring the range of materials that exhibit inorganic phototropic growth, examining the generality of the phenomenon by expanding phototropic reactivity to light-induced controlled etching of materials, and using phototropic growth to create materials with unique three-dimensional properties.  The experimental work is being integrated with modeling and simulation to develop a mechanistic understanding of inorganic phototropic growth.  The research will be integrated with solar energy and materials-discovery outreach programs led by Caltech, specifically the Juice from Juice and Project SEAL hands-on science modules for use at the high-school level throughout the country, with special emphasis on school districts comprising underrepresented groups and diverse student populations. 
 
Part 2: Technical Summary
In this project, Professor Nathan S. Lewis of the California Institute of Technology is examining the mechanisms underlying inorganic phototropic growth, i.e., the production of spontaneous, self-organized mesostructures aligned along the direction of a polarized, incoherent, uniform intensity light beam during electrodeposition of semiconductors.  The morphologies are determined by the inherent optical response of the electronic processes within semiconductors stimulated by the tunable properties (e.g. wavelength, polarization, and direction) of the light present during the electrodeposition. The process is adaptive: if the light is moved or otherwise changed, subsequent growth adapts to the changed conditions.  

To date, this phenomenon has been demonstrated experimentally only for amorphous or polycrystalline chalcogen and chalcogenide materials.  This project will investigate whether inorganic phototropic growth can be extended to other materials and how lattice structures and optoelectronic properties influence the mechanisms of inorganic phototropic growth.  The work will also investigate how substrate-electrolyte interfaces affect the early-stage development of the ordered nanostructures by studying nucleation of Se-Te alloys on substrates with varied electronic properties.  In addition, phototropic growth will be exploited to design and synthesize complex three-dimensionally structured materials with desired functionality, such as chiral metamaterials and plasmonic materials with tailored optoelectronic properties.  The experimental observations will be used in conjunction with development of a mechanistic simulation tool that combines full-wave electromagnetic calculations with Monte-Carlo-based mass addition to predict the structures produced by phototropic growth of a variety of semiconductors under arbitrary optical inputs.  This project is jointly supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry and Electronic and Photonic Materials Programs in the Division of Materials Research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many photosynthetic species, including plants such as palms, cabbage, and grass, as well as other organisms such as coral, exhibit phototropic growth, in which the growth of a biological system proceeds preferentially towards the time-averaged position of the sun. Previously, we demonstrated that electrochemical synthesis of semiconducting Se-Te alloys under illumination from an unstructured and low-intensity light source (no laser needed) can generate ordered nanoscale (one billionth of a meter) features over macroscopic (square centimeter) areas. This light-directed growth of Se-Te mimics natural phototropism and thus has been termed inorganic phototropic growth. In contrast to conventional lithographic methods used to generate microscopic structures, in which a material reacts where the light strikes the sample, in phototropic growth, the material grows towards the direction of the light field. Morphologies generated by inorganic phototropic growth are a function stimulating illumination characteristics, including wavelength (color), polarization (oscillation direction of the light wave), intensity, and direction of incidence. Inorganic phototropic growth of Se-Te using linearly polarized illumination from a low power light-emitting diode (LED) source results in the generation of ordered and highly anisotropic nanoscale lamellar arrays. The pitch (distance between two lamellae) is proportional to the wavelength and the in-plane orientation of the structure long axis aligns parallel to the direction of the polarization. Such light mediated synthesis can enable bottom-up, directed, and programmable generation of three-dimensional nanoscale structures in free space. Interfaces with nanoscale structures can exhibit useful physical properties absent in unstructured analogs. For example, the wings of the Morpho butterfly exhibit are characterized by a nanoscale structure that generates an intense blue coloration and effects asymmetric water wicking. Inorganic phototropic growth is thus a transformative technology that may have significant impact to a variety of fields including, but not limited to, optics, energy conversion, and sensing.

            Throughout the course of the award, we addressed several key knowledge gaps regarding inorganic phototropic growth to advance our fundamental understanding of the phenomenon and lay the groundwork for application of this technique as a unique morphology control process. We demonstrated that in addition to pre-established inorganic phototropic growth of Se-Te and Se-Pb, similar growth of Se-Cd, as well as Cu2O, can be effected, expanding the genus of compatible materials and indicating that inorganic phototropic growth is not a material-specific process but rather a general phenomenon inherent to light-mediated semiconductor growth. We demonstrated that anisotropic growth is a consequence of preferential material addition to sites of elevated light absorption. We noted that the self-organization of ordered structures is an emergent phenomenon based on cooperative light scattering and synergistic light absorption at the nanoscale. Additionally, we explored growth using abrupt shifts in the input wavelength and noted that the growth can dynamically respond to the new input and generate a new interfacial morphology via feature termination, fusion and splitting, enabling the generation of nanoscale 3D 'tuning fork' and 'aqueduct' morphologies. We also observed cases in which a new interfacial morphology is not generated in response to a wavelength change, but rather the growth is dictated by the underlying structure generated in the initial growth step, thus exhibiting a 'history effect'. We also showed that growth using illumination in the plane of the polarization could improve the fidelity of structures generated by phototropic growth by preventing the perseverance of initial growth defect via such a history effect.

            This project has provided training and professional development opportunities for a diverse group of graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. In addition, several undergraduates have participated in this project.  Through this project, NSF has provided opportunities for research and teaching experience and mentoring in chemistry that will contribute to the development and retention of a workforce skilled in chemistry that includes members of groups historically underrepresented in the physical sciences. Additionally, graduate students have participated in several activities to improve the scientific community at large including the Solar Energy Activity Lab (SEAL) and involvement in campus and departmental diversity efforts. SEAL is a local program that engages high school students in high-throughput experimentation to discover acid-stable catalysts for water oxidation. Graduate students working on this project also provided leadership for PRISM, a LGBTQ+ organization that aims to create a more inclusive campus environment, and participated in Caltech for Black Lives (C4BL), an ally organization that supports the work of Black Scientists and Engineers of Caltech (BSEC). Moreover, several graduate students have served as departmental Diversity, Equity, and Inclusivity coordinators.
